bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An officer may seize something without a warrant if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the thing has been produced to the officer or is in plain view, and
the officer has reasonable grounds for believing that the OHS provisions, the regulations or an order has been contravened and that the thing would afford evidence of the contravention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As soon as reasonably practicable after something is seized under subsection (1), the officer must bring the thing, or a report of it, before a justice to be dealt with in accordance with the Offence Act as if it were seized under a warrant under that Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Board may not reconsider a decision or order referred to in subsection (1) if any of the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: more than 75 days have elapsed since the decision or order was made;

a notice of appeal has been filed under section 292 [how to appeal] in respect of the decision or order.

change.changenote: Section 194 (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 232/2022 (291/2021 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2023 (BC Reg 232/2022); supported by BC Reg 96/2023, effective April 3, 2023 (BC Reg 96/2023).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Compensation to be paid under this section must not be less than $1Â 933.73 per month.

change.changenote: Section 196 BEFORE amended by 2020-20-17, effective January 1, 2021.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Permanent partial disability: exception to general rules

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies in relation to a permanent partial disability if the Board determines that the combined effect of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the worker's occupation at the time of the injury, and
the worker's disability resulting from the injury

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: is so exceptional that an amount determined under section 195 does not appropriately compensate the worker for the injury.

In making a determination under subsection (1), the Board must consider the ability of the worker to continue in the worker's occupation at the time of the injury or to adapt to another suitable occupation.
If the Board makes a determination under subsection (1), the Board may pay the worker compensation that is a periodic payment of an amount that equals 90% of the difference between

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the average net earnings of the worker before the injury, and
whichever of the following amounts the Board considers better represents the worker's loss of earnings:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the average net earnings that the worker is earning after the injury;
the average net earnings that the Board estimates the worker is capable of earning in a suitable occupation after the injury.

change.changenote: Section 198 (1.1) was added by 2022-37-5(a), effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).
Section 198 (2) and (3) BEFORE amended by 2022-37-5(b), effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the worker's hearing loss amounts to total deafness measured in the manner described in Schedule 2 [Non-Traumatic Hearing Loss] of this Act, and
there is no loss of earnings resulting from the hearing loss,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: compensation must be calculated as for a disability equivalent to 15% of total disability.
If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the worker's hearing loss does not amount to total deafness measured in the manner referred to in subsection (2), and
there is no loss of earnings resulting from the hearing loss,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: compensation must be calculated as for a lower percentage of total disability than that specified in subsection (2) and, unless otherwise ordered by the Board, must be based on the percentages set out in Schedule 2 of this Act.

change.changenote: Section 198 (4) BEFORE amended by 2022-37-5(c), effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a loss or reduction of earnings results from the hearing loss, the worker is entitled to compensation for a total or partial disability as provided under this Division.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a beneficiary designated by the worker, or
the worker's estate, if a beneficiary is not designated.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who commits an offence under a compensation provision for which no other punishment has been provided is liable on conviction to a fine not greater than $5Â 647.74.

Every person who contravenes or fails to comply with a regulation made under a compensation provision commits an offence and is liable on conviction to the fine prescribed by the regulations, but that fine must not be greater than $5Â 647.74.

change.changenote: Section 236 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 291/2021 (273/2020 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2022 (BC Reg 291/2021); supported by BC Reg 26/2022, effective February 14, 2022 (BC Reg 26/2022).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who commits an offence under a compensation provision for which no other punishment has been provided is liable on conviction to a fine not greater than $5Â 684.95.

Every person who contravenes or fails to comply with a regulation made under a compensation provision commits an offence and is liable on conviction to the fine prescribed by the regulations, but that fine must not be greater than $5Â 684.95.

change.changenote: Section 236 (1) and (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 232/2022 (291/2021 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2023 (BC Reg 232/2022); supported by BC Reg 96/2023, effective April 3, 2023 (BC Reg 96/2023).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who commits an offence under a compensation provision for which no other punishment has been provided is liable on conviction to a fine not greater than $5Â 949.56.

Every person who contravenes or fails to comply with a regulation made under a compensation provision commits an offence and is liable on conviction to the fine prescribed by the regulations, but that fine must not be greater than $5Â 949.56.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Board may assign its lien rights to a person, contractor or subcontractor who has fully discharged their liability for the amount of an assessment under section 51 by payment of it.

change.changenote: Section 265 (1) BEFORE amended by 2021-3-37, effective March 25, 2021 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite anything contained in any other Act, the amount due by an employer to the Board or, where an assignment has been made under subsection (6), its assignee, on an assessment made under this Act, or in respect of an amount which the employer is required to pay to the Board under this Act, or on a judgment for it, constitutes a lien in favour of the Board or its assignee payable in priority over all liens, charges or mortgages of every person, whenever created or to be created, with respect to the property or proceeds of property, real, personal or mixed, used in or in connection with or produced in or by the industry with respect to which the employer was assessed or the amount became payable, excepting liens for wages due to workers by their employer and liens under section 50 (1) of the Temporary Foreign Worker Protection Act.

change.changenote: Section 265 (1) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-1194(a), effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite anything contained in any other Act, the amount due by an employer to the Board or, where an assignment has been made under subsection (7), its assignee, on an assessment made under this Act, or in respect of an amount which the employer is required to pay to the Board under this Act, or on a judgment for it, constitutes a lien in favour of the Board or its assignee payable in priority over all liens, charges or mortgages of every person, whenever created or to be created, with respect to the property or proceeds of property, real, personal or mixed, used in or in connection with or produced in or by the industry with respect to which the employer was assessed or the amount became payable, excepting liens for wages due to workers by their employer and liens under section 50 (1) of the Temporary Foreign Worker Protection Act.

Section 265 (3) and (4) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-1194(b) and (c), effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The exception in subsection (1) respecting liens for wages due to workers by their employer does not apply in respect of a lien for wages that is, by section 87 (5) of the Employment Standards Act, postponed to a mortgage or debenture.

The exception in subsection (1) respecting liens under section 50 (1) of the Temporary Foreign Worker Protection Act does not apply in respect of a lien for wages that is, by section 50 (4) of the Temporary Foreign Worker Protection Act, postponed to a mortgage or debenture.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a panel is comprised of one member and that member is unable for any reason to complete the member's duties, the chair of the appeal tribunal, with the consent of all parties to the appeal, may appoint a new panel to continue to hear and determine the appeal on terms agreed to by the parties, and the vacancy does not invalidate the proceeding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair must establish a list of health professionals who may be retained to provide independent assistance or advice on the request of the appeal tribunal in an appeal.

change.changenote: Section 302 (1) BEFORE amended by 2022-37-9(a), effective April 3, 2023.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (8), if the appeal tribunal determines that independent assistance or advice from a health professional would assist in reaching a decision on an appeal, the presiding member may retain a health professional from the list under section 301 to provide such assistance or advice.

change.changenote: Section 302 (1.1) to (1.4) were added by 2022-37-9(b), effective April 3, 2023.
Section 307 (1) BEFORE amended by 2020-20-32(a), effective August 14, 2020 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party applies or on the appeal tribunal's own initiative, the appeal tribunal may amend a final decision to correct any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a clerical or typographical error;
an accidental or inadvertent error, omission or other similar mistake;
an arithmetical error made in a computation.

change.changenote: Section 307 (3) BEFORE repealed by 2020-20-32(a), effective August 14, 2020 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 90 days after being served with the final decision, a party may apply to the appeal tribunal for clarification of the final decision and the appeal tribunal may amend the final decision only if the appeal tribunal considers that the amendment will clarify the final decision.

change.changenote: Section 307 (4) BEFORE amended by 2020-20-32(b), effective August 14, 2020 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The appeal tribunal may not amend a final decision other than in those circumstances described in subsections (1) to (3).

change.changenote: Section 314 (2) BEFORE amended by 2020-20-33, effective August 14, 2020 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If information in a claim file or in any other material respecting the claim of an injured or disabled worker is disclosed for purposes of this Part to a person other than the worker, that person must not disclose the information except as permitted in circumstances described in section 235 [confidentiality â compensation claim information].

change.changenote: Section 334 BEFORE amended by 2022-37-10, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Annual adjustment of periodic payment amounts

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Board must, on or before January 1 of each year,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: determine the percentage change in the consumer price index for Canada, for all items, for the 12-month period ending on October 31 of the previous year, and
subtract 1% from the percentage change determined under paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The percentage resulting from calculations made under subsection (1) must not be greater than 4% or less than 0%.

On January 1 of each year, the Board must adjust, in accordance with subsection (4), the periodic payments of compensation made in respect of an injury or a death occurring more than 12 months before the date of the adjustment.

For the purposes of subsection (3), the Board must adjust the periodic payments of compensation to be paid in that calendar year for the injury or death by the percentage determined under subsection (1).

If the Board starts or restarts periodic payments of compensation for an injury or a death that occurred more than 12 months before the payments are started or restarted, the Board must, under this section, adjust all periodic payments as if the payments were made continuously from the date of injury or death.

change.changenote: Section 349 (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 273/2020 (241/2019 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2021 (BC Reg 273/2020); supported by BC Reg 39/2021, effective February 16, 2021 (BC Reg 39/2021).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine not greater than $5Â 647.74.

change.changenote: Part 8, Division 7, sections 355 to 357, was enacted by 2022-37-11, effective May 1, 2023.
Schedule 1, item 20 was added by BC Reg 189/2020 under RS2019-1-138, effective August 20, 2020 (BC Reg 189/2020 as amended by BC Reg 218/2020).
Schedule 2 BEFORE re-enacted by 2022-37-12, effective November 24, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:schedule.bcl:lefttext: Complete loss of hearing in both ears equals 15% of total disability. Complete loss of hearing in one ear with no loss in the other equals 3% of total disability.

oasis:line.in:strong: Loss of Hearing in Decibels Measured in Each Ear in Turn
Ear Most Affected PLUS Ear Least Affected

bcl:schedule.bcl:lefttext: The loss of hearing in decibels in the first column is the arithmetic average of thresholds of hearing measured in each ear in turn by pure tone, air conduction audiometry at frequencies of 500, 1Â 000 and 2Â 000 Hertzian waves, the measurements being made with an audiometer calibrated according to standards prescribed by the Board.

change.changenote: Schedule 2, section 2 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 18/2023 under RS2019-1-145, effective May 15, 2023 (BC Reg 18/2023).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Loss of hearing is measured

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by calculating the average of the threshold of hearing in each ear measured at the frequencies of 500, 1Â 000 and 2Â 000 Hertz, in turn, by pure-tone air-conduction audiometry, and
using an audiometer calibrated by a facility that meets the requirements established by the Board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 198 (2) of this Act, a loss of hearing in the range of decibels set out in columnÂ 1 of itemÂ 10 of the table in this Schedule constitutes a complete loss of hearing.

change.changenote: Schedule 2, section 3 (b) and (c) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 18/2023 under RS2019-1-145, effective May 15, 2023 (BC Reg 18/2023).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the maximum percentage of total disability for a complete loss of hearing in one ear and no loss of hearing in the other ear isÂ 3%, and
the maximum percentage of total disability for a complete loss of hearing in both ears isÂ 15%.

change.changenote: Schedule 2, table BEFORE amended by BC Reg 18/2023 under RS2019-1-145, effective May 15, 2023 (BC Reg 18/2023).

oasis:entry.oasis:line:
Column 2
Percentage of Disability for Ear Most Affected

Column 3
Percentage of Disability for Ear Least Affected
